Pic/AFP; (right) Lucknow Super Giants's captain KL Rahul. Pic/AFP\n\nThe battle for the Playoffs is hotting up. Four teams, who are better placed than the bottom four are in the fray for the third and fourth spots as the league phase enters the final stretch. Kolkata Knight Riders and Rajasthan Royals are perched at the top.\n\nWednesday's match between hosts Sunrisers Hyderabad and Lucknow Super Giants at the Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium is crucial as the winner will get one step closer to the Playoffs.\n\nBoth teams have 12 points each from 11 matches with six wins and five losses. Both will also keep an eye on the run-rate as it will be vital in the end as Chennai Super Kings and Delhi Capitals are the other two potential contenders in the race.\n\nSunrisers have had a roller-coaster ride this season. Before losing to Mumbai Indians by a big margin they barely managed to squeak past RR by one run in their last home match.\n\nThis season, SRH have a 3-2 record at home. As Cummins said after the toss in Mumbai that they need to win at least two matches for a Playoffs place. Apart from this match, SRH have to play two more matches, both at home. They host Gujarat Titans (May 16) before winding up the league phase with a match against Punjab Kings (May 19). On the other hand, LSG face DC in Delhi (May 14) and MI in Mumbai (May 17).\n\nAlso Read: Clarke propounds 'fatigued' Rohit's rest as essential pre-World Cup strategy\n\nThe trio of Travis Head, Abhisekh Sharma and Heinrich Klaasen, who were devastating with their big-hitting skills, have not produced the same red-hot form consistently that helped SRH rattle up big scores.\n\nThey have been culled and SRH have choked. In a few matches, young Nitish Reddy stood up to the challenge and in the last match, Cummins took SRH to 173 with a late cameo.\n\nBut otherwise, it has been a disappointing show in the second half of the season with even former Indian opener Mayank Agarwal failing in his comeback match in Mumbai. The SRH batters will be hoping to find their mojo in their last three matches at home.\n\nBhuvneshwar Kumar was the hero of SRH's thrilling win over RR. He has found his rhythm and that is good news for SRH. H Natarajan has been good with his yorkers while Cummins has come up with useful spells.\n\nLSG skipper KL Rahul and Marcus Stoinis have been top performers with the willow, but the former has come in for some criticism for his strike-rate. The bowlers have been a big disappointment.\n\nSRH preferred to skip Wednesday's net session, but LSG, who were scheduled to have a practice session too opted out because of rain. LSG assistant coach Sridharan Sriram said: \"Unseasonal rain and thunderstorms are expected. {"uri": "2024-05-348734114", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "08:56:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T08:56:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T08:44:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.sportskeeda.com/cricket/3-reasons-lsg-must-recall-quinton-de-kock-ipl-2024-clash-vs-srh", "title": "3 reasons why LSG must recall Quinton de Kock for IPL 2024 clash vs SRH?", "body": "Lucknow Super Giants (LSG) will take on Sunrisers Hyderabad in match number 57 of IPL 2024 at the Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium in Hyderabad on Wednesday, May 8. Both LSG and SRH have 12 points each from 11 matches, but are sixth and fourth, respectively, on the basis of the net run rate.\n\nLucknow have had a mixed time lately in IPL 2024, winning three and losing two of their last five matches. In their previous clash, they went down to Kolkata Knight Riders (KKR) by 98 runs at the Ekana Cricket Stadium. Batting first, Lucknow Super Giants were bowled out for 137 in 16.1 overs.\n\nOpener Quinton de Kock, who missed the match against Mumbai Indians (MI) due to a niggle, was not picked for the game against KKR despite being fit. We analyze three reasons why the South African cricketer must be recalled for LSG's IPL 2024 match against SRH on Wednesday.\n\n#1 Quinton de Kock has the experience to deliver in crucial matches\n\nDe Kock has had a mixed run in IPL 2024. In nine matches, he has scored 236 runs at an average of 26.22 and a strike rate of 136.41, with three half-centuries. After kicking off the tournament with four against Rajasthan Royals (RR), he registered consecutive fifties against Punjab Kings (PBKS) and Royal Challengers Bengaluru (RCB).\n\nAfter three low scores, he notched up another half-century against Chennai Super Kings (CSK), but it was followed up with scores of 0 and 8. Being one of the senior members of the team, De Kock has definitely disappointed with his inconsistent performances. However, LSG must back him as he has the experience to deliver in crucial matches.\n\nIt is no secret that if De Kock gets going, he can be unstoppable, which was witnessed during the 2023 ODI World Cup in India as well. In the IPL as well, he has had phases where he has been exceptional with the willow. Thus, there are enough convincing reasons for Lucknow Super Giants to hand him a recall.\n\n#2 LSG must play their best possible combination in crunch match\n\nThe Lucknow Super Giants vs Sunrisers Hyderabad IPL 2024 clash on Wednesday at the Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium would be extremely crucial keeping the playoffs scenario in mind.\n\nIf we look at the points table ahead of the game, Kolkata and Rajasthan occupy the top two slots with 16 points each. Apart from Lucknow and Hyderabad, Chennai and Delhi are also on 12 points each. The winner of the SRH vs LSG clash on Wednesday would move to 14 points. The loser of the contest would face a difficult task with regard to clinching a top four berth in the points table.\n\nConsidering how crucial the result of the match could prove to be in the context of qualification for playoffs, it will be important for Lucknow Super Giants to play their best possible combination against Sunrisers Hyderabad. And De Kock definitely fits into the picture in that context.\n\n#3 The Arshin Kulkarni experiment should be put on hold for now\n\nLucknow Super Giants have tried out young batter Arshin Kulkarni as opener in the last couple of matches. The 19-year-old was dismissed for a golden duck on his IPL debut against Mumbai Indians at the Ekana Cricket Stadium, trapped lbw by pacer Nuwan Thushara.\n\nIn the match against Kolkata Knight Riders, he fell for nine to a brilliant catch to Ramandeep Singh off Mitchell Starc's bowling. It would seem a bit unfair on Arshin to drop the youngster after just two failures. For now, though, Lucknow Super Giants need to focus on the bigger picture, which is qualification for the Indian Premier League 2024 playoffs.\n\nLSG's batting came a cropper in the match against KKR as the entire team folded up for 137. They have been dependent on Marcus Stoinis to deliver the goods with the willow in recent matches. Lucknow thus need to strengthen their batting department heading into the key clash against SRH. {"uri": "8114968400", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "06:28:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T06:28:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T06:27:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/cricket/inconsistent-srh-take-on-lsg-in-push-for-play-offs-spot-101715063067459.html", "title": "Inconsistent SRH take on LSG in push for play-offs spot", "body": "Hyderabad, Sunrisers Hyderabad will be eager to move on from their underwhelming batting display when they host Lucknow Super Giants in a crucial Indian Premier League match here on Wednesday.\n\nBoth teams are locked in at 12 points from 11 games with SRH making the top four cut based on a slightly superior net run rate of -0.065 compared to LSG's -0.371.\n\nThe Sunrisers find themselves in a fierce competition for the top four spot with Kolkata Knight Riders , Rajasthan Royals and Chennai Super Kings stationed above them on the points table.\n\nThe winner of the duel will take a leap in the playoff race.\n\nThe Pat Cummins-led side has ample talent but has been unable to hold on to a winning run recently. Sunrisers have lost three of their last four matches, mainly because their destructive batting line-up hasn't delivered.\n\nIn their last match against Mumbai Indians, which they lost by seven wickets, they failed to put up a good target on the board, which has been their strong suit this season.\n\nBarring Travis Head, who has been their stand out performer, the other batters in the side have faced a recent slump.\n\nAfter displaying his power-hitting ability, young opener Abhishek Sharma has breached the 30-run mark just once in the last four games.\n\nAnd while SRH head coach Daniel Vettori has conceded that the openers are not expected to do the job all the time, the middle order needs to step up.\n\nThe flamboyant Heinrich Klaasen has also been unable to strike the ball consistently and Nitish Reddy too has been patchy.\n\nThe bowlers have fared better compared to their batting counterparts.\n\nT Natarajan has been consistent with the ball while seasoned seamer Bhuvneshwar Kumar also seems to have found his mojo after his incisive spell helped SRH eke out a one-run win against RR.\n\nLSG, on the other hand, have to get over their overall lacklustre display against Kolkata Knight Riders, when they not only conceded the first-ever 200 plus score at the Ekana Stadium but also folded their innings at 137.\n\nIt was a day when skipper KL Rahul failed to anchor the innings while the likes of Marcus Stoinis and Nicholas Pooran were unable to get the big shots when needed.\n\nAyush Badoni has had a subdued run in this IPL and the uncapped Indian player would be keen to shrug off the rustiness.\n\nLSG's struggles with the ball have been majorly due to the lack of firepower in their pace-bowling department.\n\nWith tearaway pacer Mayank Yadav ruled out of the IPL and left-arm pacer Mohsin Khan also picking up an injury, the onus will be on Afghan quick Naveen-ul-Haq, young Yash Thakur, Stoinis and spinners Krunal Pandya and Ravi Bishnoi to deliver.\n\nSquads:\n\nSunrisers Hyderabad: Abhishek Sharma, Travis Head, Heinrich Klaasen , Aiden Markram, Abdul Samad, Nitish Reddy, Shahbaz Ahmed, Pat Cummins , Bhuvneshwar Kumar, Jaydev Unadkat, T {"uri": "8118382907", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "03:15:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T03:15:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T03:15:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.rediff.com/cricket/report/ipl-2024-power-hitters-head-abhishek-stun-lsg/20240509.htm", "title": "Head, Abhishek's Records Galore!", "body": "Photographs: BCCI\n\nSunrisers Hyderabad delivered a dominant performance against Lucknow Super Giants. Their bowlers stifled LSG's batting, restricting them to 165.\n\nThe chase was even more clinical. Openers Travis Head and Abhishek Sharma unleashed a record-breaking Powerplay assault, hammering 107 runs in just six overs.\n\nHead finished unbeaten on a staggering 89 off 30 balls, while Sharma smashed a blazing 75 off 28 deliveries. This ruthless display secured a 10 wicket win for SRH in a mere 9.4 overs.\n\nThe victory propelled SRH to number 3 on the points table with a significant boost to their net run rate.\n\nTravis Head\n\nThe night belonged to Travis Head. In a display of sheer dominance, Head led SRH to a crushing victory over LSG, chasing down the target of 166 with a record-breaking performance.\n\nHead wasted no time in dismantling LSG's bowling attack. He picked boundaries at will, showcasing his exceptional ability to handle both pace and spin. His off-driven six off Ravi Bishnoi's back foot was a clear example of his audacious strokeplay.\n\nHead's relentless assault continued throughout the innings. He ended unbeaten on 89 off just 30 balls, peppering his knock with 8 fours and 8 sixes. It was a masterclass in power-hitting, with his fifty coming off a mere 16 balls -- the joint-fastest in IPL history and his fourth fifty within the Powerplay this season, a new IPL record!\n\nHead wasn't alone in this carnage. Partnering with Abhishek Sharma, the duo formed a destructive opening partnership. They took advantage of LSG's decision to start with spin, dismantling Krishnappa Gowtham in particular.\n\nThe left-handed pair put on a hundred between them inside the Powerplay, a feat they've achieved twice this IPL, setting the record for the highest Powerplay scores in all T20 cricket on both occasions.\n\nHead continued his dominance throughout the innings, ensuring there was no possibility of a comeback from LSG. His record-breaking Powerplay assault effectively sealed the victory for SRH in just 9.4 overs.\n\nAbhishek Sharma\n\nSRH's chase began cautiously, but Abhishek Sharma was the spark that ignited a firework display. He wasted no time in dismantling LSG's bowling, starting with a powerful cut off Yash Thakur in the second over.\n\nThis set the tone for his explosive 75 not out off just 28 balls, peppered with 8 fours and 6 sixes. His aggressive style was a masterclass in power-hitting.\n\nHe formed a destructive partnership with his fellow opener, Travis Head. This duo, known for stunning bowlers throughout the season, picked up right where they left off. They displayed an uncanny ability to find the boundary regardless of pace, length, or field placement.\n\nNearly half of the balls they faced (30 out of 58) found the ropes, showcasing their dominance.\n\nBoth Head and Sharma were in a zone, leaving LSG bowlers with no answers. Their ruthless display effectively dismantled any plans LSG might have had, putting the chase firmly in SRH's control.\n\nAyush Badoni\n\nAfter a sluggish start for LSG, the middle overs became the Ayush Badoni show. In the 14th over, he unleashed his fury on T Natarajan's left-arm pace, hammering three boundaries and a staggering 17 runs. This fearless display marked a turning point, injecting much-needed momentum into the innings.\n\nPartnering with Nicholas Pooran, Badoni didn't hold back. They combined for a quickfire 99-run stand, showcasing their aggressive intent from the very first ball. Any loose delivery was met with punishment, showcasing his ability to capitalise on opportunities.\n\nThe youngster displayed a wide array of strokes, including some cheeky cuts and sweeps, en route to his fastest IPL fifty -- a mere 28 balls.\n\nThis redemption knock was long overdue for Badoni. After a season of waiting for his breakout moment, he finally delivered, silencing doubters and repaying the faith shown by LSG.\n\nBadoni's aggressive knock peppered with 9 boundaries breathed life into the LSG innings, taking them from a precarious position to a respectable total. It was a testament to his talent and ability to accelerate under pressure, even on a challenging pitch where the ball stopped and timing shots proved difficult for other batsmen.\n\nBadoni proved that with the right approach and adaptability, scoring runs was possible.\n\nNicholas Pooran\n\nElecting to bat, LSG found themselves in a precarious position at 66/4 after 11.2 overs. However, Nicholas Pooran stepped up to the challenge, forming a crucial unbeaten partnership with Badoni that revived their innings.\n\nPooran showcased his aggressive batting style, peppering the boundaries with aplomb. He was on the verge of a well-deserved fifty, needing just 6 runs off the last ball. Unfortunately, a powerful shot towards the ropes was brilliantly stopped by Nitish Reddy, denying Pooran his milestone by a whisker. While replays suggested it might have cleared the boundary, the umpires' call stood.\n\nDespite the last-ball heartbreak, Pooran's blistering 48 off just 26 balls was instrumental in LSG reaching a respectable total of 165/4 on a sluggish pitch.\n\nHe, along with Badoni, displayed exceptional adaptability, looking like they were batting on a different surface compared to their struggling team-mates.\n\nWHICH BATTER GETS YOUR VOTE!", "source": {"uri": "rediff.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rediff.com India Ltd."}, "authors": [{"uri": "laxmi_negi@rediff.com", "name": "Laxmi Negi", {"uri": "2024-05-350067729", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "10:11:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T10:11:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T09:44:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://weeklyvoice.com/ipl-2024-no-one-plays-better-spin-than-travis-abhishek-sharma-praises-fellow-srh-opener-after-win-over-lsg/", "title": "IPL 2024: 'No one plays better spin than Travis', Abhishek Sharma praises fellow SRH opener after win over LSG", "body": "Hyderabad, May 9 (VOICE) The Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) young opener player Abhishek Sharma showered praises on his opening partner Travis Head, stating that Australian batters have a unique ability to handle spin bowling like no other.\n\nSRH picked up their seventh win of the IPL 2024 after they stormed through to a 10-wicket victory over Lucknow Super Giants (LSG) at the Rajiv Gandhi International Cricket Stadium.\n\nLSG batting first scored 165 runs and managed to score only 27 runs in the Power-play. In response, the home team successfully chased down the target of 166 runs in 9.4 overs, courtesy of explosive batting from Head (89 off 30) and Abhishek (75 off 28), for a crucial victory and moving to No. 3 in the standings.\n\n\"I don't think anyone plays better spin than Travis. The shots he hit off K Gowtham, normally batters can't do that, that shows how special he is. He's very clear, whenever I talk to him, the way he compliments me, I have always been a big fan of him over the last year that I have followed him. When our understanding was established and our partnership improved, we became good friends off the pitch and have started spending more time,\" said Abhishek on Jio Cinema while speaking on his relationship with Head.\n\nAbhishek, who smashed eight boundaries and six maximums during his sensational knock against LSG, said his fearless approach was something \"he took on during the Syed Mushtaq Ali Trophy.\"\n\n\"I think this approach was something I took on during the Syed Mushtaq Ali Trophy. I feel when I play this way, look at the ball, and react, my shots come off better and the bowler comes under pressure. I always thought if I play in the IPL, I'll try to maintain this. Our support staff and Pat (Cummins), the way they think, I have never seen anyone else think like that. They're like, 'Go out there and express yourself. Play as aggressively as you can, we'll back you.' I think that matters a lot,\" he said.\n\nSharma also discussed how he tackled the LSG bowlers and said, \"They were bowling cutters in the middle. I thought the cutters could slow down on their way, but Travis and I had planned to play it the way you would hit a spinner with the spin. So, if it's an off-cutter, we look to hit towards long-off covers. {"uri": "8117902021", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:36:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:36:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T18:36:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.rediff.com/cricket/report/this-is-unreal-batting-ipl-2024-rahul-head-sharma/20240508.htm", "title": "'This is unreal batting'", "body": "IMAGE: Chasing a modest 166, Travis Head (89 not out, 30 balls, 8x4s, 8x6s) and Abhishek Sharma (75 not out, 28 balls, 8x4s, 6x6s) toyed with LSG bowlers, finding boundaries and sixes at will to canter home in just 9.4 overs. Photograph: BCCI\n\nLucknow Super Giants skipper KL Rahul on Wednesday said they were completely outplayed by the incredible power-hitting of Sunrisers Hyderabad's openers Travis Head and Abhishek Sharma, terming it \"unreal batting.\"\n\nHead and Sharma added another chapter to their remorseless domination over bowlers while carving lightning fast unbeaten fifties to power SRH to a convincing 10-wicket win over LSG in a crucial IPL match.\n\nScorecard\n\nChasing a modest 166, Head (89 not out, 30 balls, 8x4s, 8x6s) and Sharma (75 not out, 28 balls, 8x4s, 6x6s) toyed with LSG bowlers, finding boundaries and sixes at will to canter home in just 9.4 overs.\n\n\"I am at lost for words. We have watched that kind of batting on TV. But this is unreal batting. Everything seemed to find the middle of the bat. Kudos to their skills. They have worked hard on their six hitting skills.\n\n\"They didn't give us a chance to know what the pitch played in the second innings. It was hard to stop them as they teed off from ball one,\" he said.\n\nThis was after SRH bowlers started brilliantly before Badoni (55 not out off 30 balls) and Pooran (48 not out off 25 balls) stitched crucial 95-runs off 55 balls for the unbeaten fifth-wicket stand to guide LSG to a competitive 165 for four on a sluggish pitch.\n\nRahul blamed the defeat on their poor display with the bat in powerplay, from which they scored just 27 runs for the loss of two wickets.\n\n\"Once you are on the losing side, there are question marks on the decisions taken. We were 40-50 runs short. When we lost wickets in the powerplay, we couldn't get any momentum.\n\n\"Ayush (Badoni) and Nicky (Nicholas Pooran) batted well to get us to 166. But even if we would have got 240, they could have chased it as well,\" he admitted.\n\nSRH skipper Pat Cummins said that it was an \"unreal\" batting display from Head and Sharma.\n\n\"The boys (Head and Sharma) have had a fantastic season, but to win this with less than 10 overs played is unreal,\" he said.\n\n\"We just let them go, they are two guys who are very positive and I'm a bowler, it is tough for me to give them any inputs.\"\n\nCummins was effusive in his praise for both Head and Sharma.\n\n\"He's (Head) been like this for 2 years, he hits the tough areas, hits the middle a lot, might not be super conventional.\n\n\"(Abhishek) Just an incredible player of spin and pace. With just 2 fielders out, it is really difficult for the bowlers against them,\" he said.\n\nIPL 2024", "source": {"uri": "rediff.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rediff.com India Ltd."}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucknow_Super_Giants", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lucknow Super Giants"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travis_Head", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Travis Head"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batting_(cricket)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Batting (cricket)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abhishek_Sharma_(cricketer,_born_2000)", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Abhishek Sharma (cricketer, born 2000)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunrisers_Hyderabad", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Sunrisers Hyderabad"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Over_(cricket)", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Over (cricket)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boundary_(cricket)", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Boundary (cricket)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K._L._Rahul", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "K. {"uri": "2024-05-348946641", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "11:46:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T11:46:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T11:38:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.sportskeeda.com/cricket/3-changes-srh-must-make-ipl-2024-clash-vs-lsg", "title": "3 changes SRH must make for IPL 2024 clash vs LSG", "body": "Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) will begin their final home leg of IPL 2024 tonight (May 8). They will play their last three home matches over the next 11 days, with the first one scheduled to be held tonight against the Lucknow Super Giants (LSG).\n\nSRH and LSG will meet only once in IPL 2024, and the match will take place tonight. The two franchises are alive in the race to the playoffs. Both teams have 12 points from 11 matches and are separated only because of net run rate.\n\nThe Orange Army played their previous IPL 2024 match earlier this week, where the Mumbai Indians defeated them by seven wickets. SRH will aim to get back to the winning track tonight. They will have to make some changes to their tactics to defeat the Lucknow Super Giants.\n\nIn this listicle, we will look at the three changes which SRH should make for their next match against LSG in IPL 2024.\n\n#1 Rahul Tripathi in for Mayank Agarwal\n\nThe number three batting position has been a headache for the Sunrisers Hyderabad. The opening pair of Abhishek Sharma and Travis Head has done its job to perfection, but if the opposition breaks the opening stand early, the Hyderabad-based franchise have not had a solid number three batter who can stabilize the innings.\n\nHyderabad have two capped Indian batters in their squad, namely Rahul Tripathi and Mayank Agarwal. Both batters have had a forgettable season so far. Tripathi, who made his T20I debut for India last year, has got to play only two matches, where he has aggregated 31 runs.\n\nAgarwal made his return to the match squad for the last match against Mumbai Indians and returned with five runs from six balls. Perhaps, Hyderabad should give one more opportunity to Tripathi because he showed enormous intent in the previous seasons. If Tripathi gets going, he can solve the top-order problem for Hyderabad.\n\n#2 Glenn Phillips in for Marco Jansen\n\nIt is a bit difficult to understand why Sunrisers Hyderabad picked five pace-bowling options in their match squad for the last two matches. Pat Cummins, Bhuvneshwar Kumar, T Natarajan, and Nitish Kumar Reddy have been regular members of the team.\n\nPace-bowling all-rounder Marco Jansen got to play against Rajasthan Royals and Mumbai Indians but proved to be quite expensive on both occasions. Since the team already has quality options in the pace attack, they can think of leaving Jansen out for Glenn Phillips, who can add more muscle to the batting. Plus, he is a better fielder than Jansen and is also a handy part-time spinner.\n\n#3 SRH should use the Impact Player wisely\n\nIn the last match against Mumbai Indians, Hyderabad surprisingly introduced Sanvir Singh as an Impact Player to strengthen the batting in the 18th over. Singh finished with eight runs off seven balls and did not bowl in the second innings.\n\nMany fans felt that the team management could have allowed Bhuvneshwar Kumar to come in to bat instead of Sanvir and then introduce a specialist bowler as an Impact Player. Check Possible Outcomes | \ud83c\udfcf LatestLY", "body": "The IPL 2024 has entered it's business end and most teams have only three to four games left in the competition. Despite of that a team is yet to confirm qualification and none of them has been knocked out of the playoff race. KKR and RR are at the top two position, closest to the playoffs, followed by SRH, CSK and LSG who are still fighting out for the next two spots. DC is making a resurgent run after a poor start and is still in the mix. GT, RCB, PBKS and MI are the four teams who are in the bottom four and will need a miracle to change fortunes. A lot of the fate of the IPL 2024 points table will depend on the SRH vs LSG match. What Happens if SRH vs LSG IPL 2024 Match Is Washed Out? Know About All Possible Scenarios That Can Take Place.\n\nSunrisers Hyderabad will host Lucknow Super Giants at their home at the Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium in Hyderabad. They have won six games till now and suffered five losses. Lucknow Super Giants have also won and lost same number of games but their loss in the last game against KKR has pushed them down the table with a poor net run rate. If SRH wins the game, they will take a big step towards playoff qualification. Not only this win will push them forward in the competition, it will also eliminate a possible playoff contender in LSG as they will be able to reach a maximum of 16 points and will have to carry the poor net run rate.\n\nIf LSG wins, then they will return to level playing fields. They will remain in the mix of four teams who can reach the 18-point mark and that will compensate for their very poor net run rate. Although, the SRH vs LSG game will have it's impact beyond the two teams. If SRH wins, MI will be the first team to get knocked out of the playoff race. They can reach a maximum of 12 points and if SRH move to 14 point with their win over LSG, they will be knocked out as LSG is yet to play DC who are both at 12-point mark. One of them will definitely reach beyond 12 in that game. Happy Birthday Pat Cummins! Sunrisers Hyderabad Extends Heartfelt Wishes to Their Captain As He Turns 31.\n\nPBKS, RCB and GT have lost 7 games each and yet have the opportunity to make it to the 14 points mark and wait for other results to go in their favour. But if SRH win against LSG, the PBKS vs RCB game at Mullanpur becomes a knockout as the loser will be eliminated from the playoff race, as that team will make it to 12-point mark as the maximum. Gujarat Titans are also in a similar situation but with fixtures in their favour, despite of SRH winning, they will have remain alive with the condition of winning all their next games. {"uri": "8118789833", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "08:48:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T08:48:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:47:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://crickettimes.com/2024/05/ipl-2024-kl-rahul-pat-cummins-offer-their-views-on-the-hyderabad-pitch-after-srh-destroys-lsg/", "title": "IPL 2024: KL Rahul, Pat Cummins offer their views on the Hyderabad pitch after SRH destroys LSG", "body": "In a significant turnaround after just one victory in their preceding four matches, Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) significantly bolstered their playoff aspirations with a resounding ten-wicket victory over Lucknow Super Giants (LSG) in Match 57 of the Indian Premier League (IPL) 2024 on Wednesday (May 8). Pursuing a target of 166, Travis Head and Abhishek Sharma unleashed a relentless onslaught on the LSG bowlers, guiding their team to victory in a mere 9.4 overs. This remarkable feat not only secured the win but also etched its place in history as the fastest 150+ run chase ever recorded in T20 cricket.\n\nSRH dominated the powerplay, reaching an impressive 107/0, nearly quadrupling LSG's meager score of 27/2 in the first six overs. This stands as the lowest powerplay total for LSG in their brief IPL history. Despite initial perceptions of a sluggish pitch, Head and Abhishek dispelled any doubts with their aggressive batting display, showcasing their dominance regardless of the conditions.\n\nFollowing the match, LSG's skipper KL Rahul expressed his belief that early wickets in the powerplay could have potentially altered the course of the game, but lamented LSG's failure to capitalize in that crucial phase. He noted that while the pitch conditions remained relatively unchanged, the aggressive mindset and freedom exhibited by Head and Abhishek made it challenging to contain them. Rahul emphasized that when batters are in such form and rhythm, it becomes exceedingly difficult to halt their momentum.\n\n\"I think the pitch didn't change too much, but when you have two batters coming in with that kind of mindset and freedom, and they just tee off from ball one and everything's connecting, it's really hard to stop them. The only way to stop teams like that is to get wickets in the powerplay. Unfortunately, if you don't do that, you're in trouble. And that's what we experienced today,\" Rahul said during the post-match press conference.\n\nHowever, KL Rahul conceded that despite falling short by 40-50 runs in the first innings, the aggressive intent displayed by SRH suggested that even a target of 240 would have been achievable on the night, ultimately sealing LSG's fate.\n\n\"Was hard to stop them as they teed off from ball one. Once you are on the losing side, there are questions marks on the decisions taken. We were 40-50 runs short. When we lost wickets in the powerplay, we couldn't get any momentum. Ayush and Nicky batted well to get us to 166. But even if we would have got 240, they could have chased it as well,\" the 32-year-old added.\n\nAfter the game, SRH's captain Pat Cummins humorously suggested the possibility of changing the pitch midway through the clash, implying that perhaps Head and Abhishek had already done so. {"uri": "2024-05-349937367", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "08:13:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T08:13:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:08:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://weeklyvoice.com/ipl-2024-i-dont-think-we-could-have-ever-expected-chasing-it-like-that-says-travis-head/", "title": "IPL 2024: I don't think we could have ever expected chasing it like that, says Travis Head", "body": "Hyderabad, May 9 (VOICE) Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) batting star Travis Head 'never expected' the way he and along with fellow opener Abhishek Sharma chased down the total of 166 in 9.4 overs in the IPL 2024 match against Lucknow Super Giants (SRH) on Wednesday night at Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium.\n\nHead smashed a 16-ball half-century with some astonishing display of cricketing shots and remained unbeaten on 89 off just 33 deliveries to guide his team home. He along with his opening duo Abhishek Sharma stitched up 166 runs opening partnership and hammered 107 runs in the power play in comparison to LSG's 27.\n\n\"I don't think we could have ever expected chasing it like that,\" acknowledged Head at the post-match press conference. \"It looked like a tough wicket in the first innings, it looked like it was holding and a slow pitch. I guess, knowing that as a batter, you know that the powerplay is important. (We were) trying to maximise that and we played beautifully, we were able to get ahead of the rate, which is nice. And once we got going in the first two or three overs, it was just about trying to maximise that as much as we can and I felt we picked our targets and played very well,\" he said.\n\nSRH obliterated LSG's challenge by first stifling them with the new ball and then launching a sensational chase of 166 in just 9.4 overs, the highest 10-over score in any T20. In all T20 cricket, only seven times 100 or more been scored in the powerplay, SRH have the two top scores, both in IPL 2024.\n\n\"You always want to perform, you always want to be consistent, you always want to try and be doing the job; it's not going to always happen in T20 cricket (but) I felt the way we have been playing is great. We're going to have ups and downs, we've had that. Nice to be able to chase a score tonight after being put under pressure by them batting (first).\n\n\"A couple of times we've chased throughout the season, we've been put under pressure. To be able to do the job tonight, and chasing, (it feels great). Looking forward to the next two games being at home as well,\" said Head.\n\nHead and Abhishek have combined for three century stands in the IPL with two of the, coming in the powerplay. SRH is the only side with more than one century opening stand in the IPL 2024.\n\n\"It's nice to just come here and contribute. I wasn't sure if I was going to play. Nice to get a go, nice to be performing, and the partnership with Abhi has been fantastic. He's such an exciting talent for Indian cricket, he's exceptional. We complement each other well and he's very, very enjoyable to be around. He's so excited and thinks about the game, he's got loads of energy, so he's a great partnership to be involved in,\" Head said of the opening stand before he added that the middle order has also played a key role for SRH.\n\n\"I guess the Kings game (against Punjab Kings) is a blueprint for us in the way we're able to go about the game. It's not always going to work at the top of the order, we are going to lose wickets, but we want to be brave through the whole middle. Nitish [Reddy] has played some unbelievable innings, obviously we've got Klassy (Heinrich Klaasen) and (Abdul) Samad tops it off for us...\n\n\"Everyone is high on confidence, everyone is playing well, we're not dependent on the top order. PTI\n\nThe remorseless domination of Travis Head and Abhishek Sharma, who carved lightning fast fifties, helped Sunrisers Hyderabad mount the fastest chase of a 160-plus target en route their convincing 10-wicket win over Lucknow Super Giants in the IPL match here today.\n\nChasing a modest target of 166, Head (89 not out, 30 balls, 8x4, 8x6) and Sharma (75 not out, 28 balls, 8x4, 6x6) toyed with LSG bowlers, finding boundaries and sixes at will to canter home in just 9.4 overs.\n\n\"Nice to get 360 and get to the parts of the ground I have not been to. Dan and Pat have asked me to play that way. We want to maximise the powerplay. It is not going to work every time but we want to go for it,\" said Head.\n\nThe win propelled SRH to the third position in the standings with 14 points from 12 games, while LSG are struggling at the sixth spot with 12 points from the same number of matches.\n\nThe result also meant that five-time champions Mumbai Indians, currently ninth with eight points from 12 matches, are out of the playoff race.\n\nThe dance of destruction by Head and Sharma even left the legendary Sachin Tendulkar gushing.\n\n\"A destructive opening partnership would be an understatement tonight. Had these boys batted first, they would've scored 300,\" Tendulkar posted online.\n\nThe Head and Sharma show came after SRH bowlers started brilliantly before losing the plot a bit.\n\nAyush Badoni (55 not out off 30 balls) and Nicholas Pooran (48 not out off 25 balls) stitched crucial 95 runs off 55 balls for the unbeaten fifth-wicket stand to guide LSG to 165/4. All the credit to Travis, the way he starts, first two or three balls goes to the boundaries. Chopra has described Abhishek's performance in the ongoing IPL 2024 as a compelling story.\n\nComparing his hitting style with Travis Head's, Chopra said that the young opener's technique is cleaner, and his smooth backlift reminds him of legendary all-rounder Yuvraj Singh's batting.\n\nThe commentator also praised the SRH opener's well-executed downswing and called his batting classy, featuring traditional shots. He also mentioned Head and Abhishek's strike rate and said that the India all-rounder is not far behind the Australian star while highlighting his finesse and power-hitting ability.\n\nAakash Chopra said in a video uploaded on his YouTube Channel: \"Abhishek Sharma is a very good story. If I compare their (Abhishek and Head's) hitting styles, Abhishek's style seems cleaner to me. The backlift comes nicely, it reminds you slightly of Yuvraj Singh, and the downswing is very good. You see class in his batting.\n\nIt seems like Head is taking people's class, as though he is just beating them up, and it seems just like an extension of cricketing shots in his (Abhishek's) case. On a sluggish surface, the visitors opted to bat first in the hope of making better use of the pitch with the ball in the second half.\n\nHowever, it was a poor start from the Lucknow Super Giants as they could only muster 27 runs during the powerplay overs. {"uri": "8115137586", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "08:21:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T08:21:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T08:21:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.thehindu.com/sport/cricket/ipl-17-srh-vs-lsg-inconsistent-sunrisers-hyderabad-take-on-lucknow-super-giants-in-push-for-play-offs-spot/article68148657.ece", "title": "IPL-17, SRH vs LSG | Inconsistent Sunrisers Hyderabad take on Lucknow Super Giants in push for play-offs spot", "body": "Sunrisers Hyderabad will be eager to move on from their underwhelming batting display when they host Lucknow Super Giants in a crucial Indian Premier League match in Hyderabad on May 10.\n\nBoth teams are locked in at 12 points from 11 games with SRH making the top four cut based on a slightly superior net run rate of -0.065 compared to LSG's -0.371.\n\nThe Sunrisers find themselves in a fierce competition for the top four spot with Kolkata Knight Riders (16), Rajasthan Royals (16) and Chennai Super Kings (12) stationed above them on the points table.\n\nThe winner of the duel will take a leap in the playoff race.\n\nThe Pat Cummins-led side has ample talent but has been unable to hold on to a winning run recently. Sunrisers have lost three of their last four matches, mainly because their destructive batting line-up hasn't delivered.\n\nIn their last match against Mumbai Indians, which they lost by seven wickets, they failed to put up a good target on the board, which has been their strong suit this season.\n\nBarring Travis Head, who has been their stand out performer, the other batters in the side have faced a recent slump.\n\nAfter displaying his power-hitting ability, young opener Abhishek Sharma has breached the 30-run mark just once in the last four games.\n\nAnd while SRH head coach Daniel Vettori has conceded that the openers are not expected to do the job all the time, the middle order needs to step up.\n\nThe flamboyant Heinrich Klaasen has also been unable to strike the ball consistently and Nitish Reddy too has been patchy.\n\nThe bowlers have fared better compared to their batting counterparts.\n\nT. Natarajan has been consistent with the ball while seasoned seamer Bhuvneshwar Kumar also seems to have found his mojo after his incisive spell helped SRH eke out a one-run win against RR.\n\nLSG, on the other hand, have to get over their overall lacklustre display against Kolkata Knight Riders, when they not only conceded the first-ever 200 plus score at the Ekana Stadium but also folded their innings at 137.\n\nIt was a day when skipper KL Rahul failed to anchor the innings while the likes of Marcus Stoinis and Nicholas Pooran were unable to get the big shots when needed.\n\nAyush Badoni has had a subdued run in this IPL and the uncapped Indian player would be keen to shrug off the rustiness.\n\nLSG's struggles with the ball have been majorly due to the lack of firepower in their pace-bowling department.\n\nWith tearaway pacer Mayank Yadav ruled out of the IPL and left-arm pacer Mohsin Khan also picking up an injury, the onus will be on Afghan quick Naveen-ul-Haq, young Yash Thakur, Stoinis and spinners Krunal Pandya and Ravi Bishnoi to deliver.\n\nSquads\n\nSunrisers Hyderabad: Abhishek Sharma, Travis Head, Heinrich Klaasen (wk), Aiden Markram, Abdul Samad, Nitish Reddy, Shahbaz Ahmed, Pat Cummins (c), Bhuvneshwar Kumar, Jaydev Unadkat, T Natarajan, Mayank Markande, Umran Malik, Anmolpreet Singh, Glenn Phillips (wk), Rahul Tripathi, Washington Sundar, Upendra Yadav (wk), Jhathavedh Subramanyan, Sanvir Singh, Vijayakanth Viyaskanth, Fazalhaq Farooqi, Marco Jansen, Akash Maharaj Singh, Mayank Agarwal.\n\nLucknow Super Giants: Quinton de Kock, KL Rahul (c & wk), Deepak Hooda, Ayush Badoni, Marcus Stoinis, Nicholas Pooran (wk), Krunal Pandya, Ravi Bishnoi, Mohsin Khan, Shamar Joseph, Yash Thakur, Manimaran Siddharth, Prerak Mankad, Arshad Khan, Krishnappa Gowtham, Amit Mishra, Kyle Mayers, Ashton Turner, Matt Henry, Naveen-ul-Haq, Devdutt Padikkal, Yudhvir Singh Charak, Mayank Yadav, Arshin Kulkarni.\n\nMatch starts 7:30 p.m. IST.\n\nRead Comments", On the final ball of the 20th over, SRH captain Pat Cummins bowled a high full toss outside off to Nicholas Pooran and the latter sliced it towards sweeper cover.\n\nWhile the ball was looking destined to go for a six, Nitish Reddy made a brilliant effort to stop it from landing on the other side of the boundary cushion. The SRH allrounder timed his jump to perfection and caught the ball as well while being airborne. And as he was falling on the boundary cushion, he released the ball before falling on the rope.\n\nHe, however, could not release the ball with force. As a result, the ball ended up touching the boundary cushion. The umpires gave it as a four and KL Rahul was not happy with the decision. Sunrisers have lost three of their last four matches, mainly because their destructive batting line-up hasn't delivered.\n\nIn their last match against Mumbai Indians, which they lost by seven wickets, they failed to put up a good target on the board, which has been their strong suit this season.\n\nBarring Travis Head, who has been their stand out performer, the other batters in the side have faced a recent slump.\n\nAfter displaying his power-hitting ability, young opener Abhishek Sharma has breached the 30-run mark just once in the last four games.\n\nAnd while SRH head coach Daniel Vettori has conceded that the openers are not expected to do the job all the time, the middle order needs to step up.\n\nThe flamboyant Heinrich Klaasen has also been unable to strike the ball consistently and Nitish Reddy too has been patchy.\n\nThe bowlers have fared better compared to their batting counterparts.\n\nT Natarajan has been consistent with the ball while seasoned seamer Bhuvneshwar Kumar also seems to have found his mojo after his incisive spell helped SRH eke out a one-run win against RR.\n\nLSG, on the other hand, have to get over their overall lacklustre display against Kolkata Knight Riders, when they not only conceded the first-ever 200 plus score at the Ekana Stadium but also folded their innings at 137.\n\nIt was a day when skipper KL Rahul failed to anchor the innings while the likes of Marcus Stoinis and Nicholas Pooran were unable to get the big shots when needed.\n\nAyush Badoni has had a subdued run in this IPL and the uncapped Indian player would be keen to shrug off the rustiness.\n\nLSG's struggles with the ball have been majorly due to the lack of firepower in their pace-bowling department.\n\nWith tearaway pacer Mayank Yadav ruled out of the IPL and left-arm pacer Mohsin Khan also picking up an injury, the onus will be on Afghan quick Naveen-ul-Haq, young Yash Thakur, Stoinis and spinners Krunal Pandya and Ravi Bishnoi to {"uri": "8118367946", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "03:03:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T03:03:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T03:01:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://wwos.nine.com.au/cricket/news-2024-ipl-travis-head-innings-highlights-sunrisers-hyderabad-v-lucknow-super-giants-highlights-reaction/3a1dedc9-6191-4d41-bfd1-dcf12938e269", "title": "'Utterly absurd' Head sends ominous World Cup message", "body": "Travis Head has given a huge glimpse into his game plan for next month's T20 World Cup in a statement innings for Sunrisers Hyderabad against a luckless Lucknow in the IPL.\n\nHead smacked a player of the match-winning 89 off just 30 balls - including a 16-ball half-century - as the Sunrisers cruised to a 10-wicket win, chasing down the target of 166 inside 10 overs.\n\nHis opening partner down the other end, Indian prodigy Abhishek Sharma smashed 75 off just 28 balls. Together, they hit 16 boundaries and 14 sixes. The innings set a new IPL record for a score inside 10 overs.\n\n\"That was a lot of fun,\" Head said in the post-match presentation.\n\n\"I was just concentrating on trying to get into good positions, watch the ball hard and react to it. Once I got a flow on in the first couple of overs and got ahead of the rate a little bit, it felt like it was a great opportunity in the powerplay to try and maximise that.\"\n\nHead shocked commentators when he belted spinner Ravi Bishnoi for six over cover off the back foot. He said it was something he had been working on in the nets in preparation for the World Cup.\n\n\"It's something I've been working on with spin, they came with off-spin again today, so something I've been working hard with and I feel like it's going to be a big part ... of the World Cup,\" Head said.\n\n\"It was nice to be able to go 360 (degrees) tonight and get it into some parts of the ground that I don't normally get it to.\"\n\nRenowned commentator and analyst Harsha Bhogle said Head batted like a \"big boss\" and put it to him that he doesn't know the meaning of the word fear.\n\n\"The last 12 months, being back in the Australian team, that's how they've wanted me to play. Having Dan (Vettori, Australia assistant coach and Sunrisers head coach) and Pat (Cummins), they've expressed they want me to go about it the same way.\n\n\"So for me it's not trying to change anything, and to maximise the powerplay. It's not going to work all the time, but as long as I can be consistent in giving myself the best opportunity, hopefully I can do the part for the team.\"\n\nThe innings saw him eclipse David Warner's decade-old record for most runs for Sunrisers in a debut season at the club.\n\nEven Lucknow captain KL Rahul was stunned.\n\n\"I'm lost for words. We've watched that batting on TV - but that was unreal. Everything was hitting the middle of the bat, kudos to their skill.\"\n\nHead reached his fifty from just 16 balls. Sharma followed not long after when he reached his 50 off only 19 balls as they raced to century-stand inside the batting power play.\n\nThe win lifted Hyderabad to third on the ladder with 14 points with two matches to play, both at home. It also gave their net run-rate a healthy lift. The huge defeat has pushed Lucknow into a tight corner for the playoffs with 12 points from 12 games.\n\nEarlier, Ayush Badoni (55) and Nicholas Pooran (48) propelled Lucknow to 4-165 with a 99-run unbeaten fifth-wicket stand after Bhuvneshwar Kumar (2-12) gave away just 12 singles and dismissed the big hitters -- Quinton de Kock (2) and Marcus Stoinis (3) -- inside the power play.\n\nHead and Sharma charged against pace and spin as Yash Thakur was smashed for 47 off his 16 balls while spinners Ravi Bishnoi and Krishnappa Gowtham gave away 63 runs off their four overs.\n\nLucknow had a moment to separate the destructive pair but Thakur couldn't hold onto a sharp one-handed catch of Sharma at short third-man when the batter was on 18 in the third over. Sharma had another escape after completing his half-century when leg-spinner Bishnoi dropped a hard two-handed return catch.\n\nEarlier, Kumar had buckled down Lucknow 27-2 in the first six overs on a tacky wicket and Rahul struggled to give the innings momentum before pulled skipper Pat Cummins to deep backward square leg and got dismissed for struggling 29 off 33 balls.\n\nPooran and Badoni {"uri": "8118567624", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "06:13:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T06:13:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T06:12:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.newsbytesapp.com/news/sports/presenting-wins-in-ipl-with-most-balls-to-spare/story", "title": "Decoding successful run chases with most balls to spare (IPL)", "body": "Sunrisers Hyderabad shattered a host of records en route to their record chase against Lucknow Super Giants in Match 57 of the 2024 Indian Premier League (IPL). Openers Travis Head and Abhishek Sharma put up a boundary-hitting exhibition as SRH accomplished the 166-run target in just 9.4 overs. Here we decode the successful chases in IPL with the most balls to spare (100+ targets).\n\nIn 2008, the now-defunct Deccan Chargers accomplished the 155-run target against Mumbai Indians with eight overs to spare (48 balls). Adam Gilchrist, who made an unbeaten 109 off 47 balls, attacked straightaway as DC were 60/0 after six overs. His opening partner VVS Laxman (37* off 26) played the second fiddle well as MI bowlers were left utterly clueless. Both openers returned unbeaten.\n\nDelhi Capitals comfortably achieved the 116-run target against Punjab Kings in 2022. Openers Prithvi Shaw and David Warner added 81 runs in the powerplay overs. While the former perished for 21, the Australian dasher made an unbeaten 60 off 30 balls. Sarfaraz Khan contributed with 12* runs as DC crossed the line with 57 balls to spare (119/1).\n\nSRH top this list, having chased down 166 versus LSG with 62 balls to spare. Head and Abhishek were equally destructive as the Super Giants bowlers had no place to hide. SRH scored 107/0 in the first six overs, the second-highest powerplay score in IPL history. While Head made an unbeaten 89 off 30 balls, Abhishek made his presence felt with a 28-ball 75*.\n\nSRH broke their own record to register the highest total after first 10 overs in the IPL. Their 167/0 came in 9.4 overs. Before this, SRH posted 158/4 against DC after 10 overs earlier this season. Meanwhile, Abhishek and Head took 34 balls to being up their 100-run stand versus LSG. It's the second-fewest balls consumed for a 100-run stand.", "source": {"uri": "newsbytesapp.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewsBytes"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The upcoming match, scheduled for Wednesday, will see the Sunrisers Hyderabad and Lucknow Super Giants facing off at the Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium in Hyderabad.\n\nThe Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) entered the game following a significant defeat to the Mumbai Indians. Despite the loss, they maintain their fourth position in the league table with three matches remaining. Returning to their home ground, SRH can expect strong support from their fans.\n\nMeanwhile, the Lucknow Super Giants (LSG) also suffered a heavy defeat in their previous match against the Kolkata Knight Riders, losing by 98 runs. This places KL Rahul's team in fifth position in the IPL standings, emphasizing the importance of winning their upcoming matches, especially with the Delhi Capitals in close pursuit.\n\nThe Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium in Hyderabad has witnessed high-scoring encounters throughout the season, with a significant number of runs scored. Captains winning the toss may opt to bat first, capitalizing on the slower conditions later in the match. {"uri": "8118469305", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "04:46:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T04:46:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T04:45:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.cricbuzz.com/cricket-news/130377/our-powerplay-compared-to-sunrisers-was-at-two-extremes-voges", "title": "'Our powerplay compared to Sunrisers was at two extremes' - Voges", "body": "\"I am lost for words. We have watched that kind of batting on TV. But this is unreal batting,\" KL Rahul, the captain of Lucknow Super Giants, told the broadcasters at the post-match presentations, summing up the second innings carnage at the Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium in Hyderabad. In what turned out to be a completely one-sided contest in Hyderabad, Travis Head and Abhishek Sharma's belligerent batting was on display yet again as they needed just 9.4 overs to chase down a target of 166.\n\nThe Super Giants posted what appeared to be a competitive total on a pitch that didn't look easy for the batters. But the SRH openers didn't even bring the pitch into the equation thanks to their ultra-aggressive approach, as a result of which several T20 records were broken again. They raced past 100 in the powerplay, becoming the first side to do so on two separate occasions, and the difference in the powerplay scores - 80 runs - told the story as SRH won with 62 deliveries to spare, the earliest a team has reached a 150-plus target in T20 cricket.\n\n\"I don't think we could have ever expected chasing it like that,\" acknowledged Head at the post-match press conference. \"It looked like a tough wicket in the first innings, it looked like it was holding and a slow pitch. I guess, knowing that as a batter, you know that the powerplay is important. (We were) trying to maximise that and we played beautifully, we were able to get ahead of the rate, which is nice. And once we got going in the first two or three overs, it was just about trying to maximise that as much as we can and I felt we picked our targets and played very well.\"\n\nAdam Voges, the consultant for LSG this season, admitted that the gulf in the powerplay between the two sides was a big factor in the outcome of the game, and praised the SRH openers for their \"incredible batting\".\n\n\"I think we're all in awe of what we've just seen. Sometimes you got to tip your hat and say well played to the opposition. (They) might have mis-hit one or two balls in the nine and bit overs that we bowled at them. Incredible batting, incredible hitting, clearly we didn't have an answer for,\" said Voges. \"I haven't spoken to the guys yet whether there was a difference in terms of the innings but clearly our powerplay compared to the Sunrisers was at the two extremes.\n\n\"What do you say, 2 for 20 odd as opposed to 100 for none, and that's the game in itself. We were put under immense pressure with the ball right from the start, we weren't able to apply the same pressure with the bat to begin with. I thought the backend of our innings was really good, [Ayush] Badoni and [Nicholas] Pooran partnership got us to...it was probably still an under par total but gave us a fighting chance at least. But that obviously was clearly not enough. We thought we at least had a total to be able to defend, We probably thought we still were a little bit short but clearly we could have got 250 and I don't think that would have been enough.\" Voges said.\n\nThe template that has worked well for SRH this season has been to bat first and post very big totals, and then find a way to restrict the opposition. But they also suffered a couple of big losses while chasing earlier in this competition. That they were able to get over the line in the chase against LSG, and do so by making a statement, has pleased Head.\n\n\"You always want to perform, you always want to be consistent, you always want to try and be doing the job; it's not going to always happen in T20 cricket (but) I felt the way we have been playing is great. We're going to have ups and downs, we've had that. Nice to be able to chase a score tonight after being put under pressure by them batting (first). A couple of times we've chased throughout the season, we've been put under pressure. To be able to do the job tonight, and chasing, (it feels great). Looking forward to the next two games being at home as well,\" said Head.\n\nHead and Abhishek have now been involved in three century stands in this IPL, making up a third of the 100-plus opening partnerships this season, and SRH are the only team to have more than one century opening stand in IPL 2024. All three century partnerships have resulted in victories for the team, emphasising the importance of the Head-Abhishek combination for SRH.\n\n\"It's nice to just come here and contribute. I wasn't sure if I was going to play. Nice to get a go, nice to be performing, and the partnership with Abhi has been fantastic. He's such an exciting talent for Indian cricket, he's exceptional. We complement each other well and he's very, very enjoyable to be around. He's so excited and thinks about the game, he's got loads of energy, so he's a great partnership to be involved in,\" Head said of the opening stand before he added that the middle order has also played a key role for SRH.\n\n\"I guess the Kings game (against Punjab Kings) is a blueprint for us in the way we're able to go about the game. It's not always going to work at the top of the order, we are going to lose wickets, but we want to be brave through the whole middle. Nitish [Reddy] has played some unbelievable innings, obviously we've got Klassy [Heinrich Klaasen] and [Abdul] Samad tops it off for us...Everyone is high on confidence, everyone is playing well, we're not dependent on the top order. Yes we are playing well but I don't think it defines the team. {"uri": "8118763320", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "08:29:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T08:29:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:28:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.rediff.com/cricket/report/never-seen-anyone-think-like-cummins-and-the-srh-support-staff-abhishek-sharma-ipl-2024/20240509.htm", "title": "Never seen anyone think like Cummins and the SRH support staff: Abhishek", "body": "IMAGE: Abhishek Sharma credited the SRH skipper and support staff for his sensational form. Photographs: BCCI\n\nThe unwavering support from skipper Pat Cummins and the entire think-tank played a big role in his success in the on-going IPL, reckoned Sunrisers Hyderabad opener Abhishek Sharma.\n\nThe 23-year-old Punjab left-hander fired from all cylinders for Hyderabad this season, making 401 runs from 12 matches and those runs have come at an awesome strike-rate of 205.\n\n\"Our support staff and Pat (Cummins), the way they think, I have never seen anyone else think like that,\" Abhishek said on JioCinema Match Centre Live after their record 10-wicket win over Lucknow Super Giants in Hyderabad on Wednesday.\n\n\"They're like, 'Go out there and express yourself. Play as aggressively as you can, we'll back you.' I think that matters a lot,\" said Abhishek, who has hit 35 sixes so far, highest by any batter this season.\n\nThe SRH openers Abhishek (75 not out off 28 balls) and Travis Head (89 not out off 30 balls) scaled down 166 in just 9.4 overs, rewriting the record for the quickest chase of 150-plus in T20 cricket.\n\nSRH's total of 167 was also the highest by any team by the end of the tenth over in men's T20s.\n\n\"I think this approach was something I took on during the Syed Mushtaq Ali Trophy,\" said Abhishek who played a key role in Punjab winning the domestic T20 title last season.\n\nAbhishek (485 runs from 10 matches) was the second highest run-getter behind Riyan Parag (510) of Assam in last season's SMAT.\n\n\"I feel when I play this way, look at the ball, and react, my shots come off better and the bowler comes under pressure. I always thought if I play in the IPL, I'll try to maintain this,\" he added.\n\n'Big fan of Head'\n\nWith Head at his explosive best, SRH have smashed many batting records this season including the highest ever IPL total of 287/3 against Royal Challengers Bengaluru.\n\nAbhishek hailed the way Head played spin.\n\n\"I don't think anyone plays spin better than Travis. The shots he hit off (Krishnappa) Gowtham, normally batters can't do that, that shows how special he is.\n\n\"He's very clear, whenever I talk to him, the way he compliments me, I have always been a big fan of him over the last year that I have followed him.\n\n\"When our understanding was established and our partnership improved, we became good friends off the pitch and have started spending more time,\" he added.\n\nAbhishek then touched upon his strategy against the LSG bowlers, especially pacers.\n\n\"They were bowling cutters in the middle. I thought the cutters could slow down on their way, but Travis and I had planned to play it the way you would hit a spinner with the spin.\n\n\"So, if it's an off-cutter, we look to hit towards long-off covers. {"uri": "8115014151", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "07:01:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T07:01:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T07:00:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.etvbharat.com/en/!sports/inconsistent-srh-take-on-lsg-in-push-for-play-offs-spot-enn24050702741", "title": "Inconsistent SRH Take On LSG in Push For Play-Offs Spot", "body": "Hyderabad: Sunrisers Hyderabad will be eager to move on from their underwhelming batting display when they host Lucknow Super Giants in a crucial Indian Premier League match here on Wednesday.\n\nBoth teams are locked in at 12 points from 11 games with SRH making the top four cut based on a slightly superior net run rate of -0.065 compared to LSG's -0.371.\n\nThe Sunrisers find themselves in a fierce competition for the top four spot with Kolkata Knight Riders (16), Rajasthan Royals (16) and Chennai Super Kings (12) stationed above them on the points table. The winner of the duel will take a leap in the playoff race.\n\nThe Pat Cummins-led side has ample talent but has been unable to hold on to a winning run recently. Sunrisers have lost three of their last four matches, mainly because their destructive batting line-up hasn't delivered. In their last match against Mumbai Indians, which they lost by seven wickets, they failed to put up a good target on the board, which has been their strong suit this season.\n\nBarring Travis Head, who has been their stand out performer, the other batters in the side have faced a recent slump. After displaying his power-hitting ability, young opener Abhishek Sharma has breached the 30-run mark just once in the last four games.\n\nAnd while SRH head coach Daniel Vettori has conceded that the openers are not expected to do the job all the time, the middle order needs to step up. The flamboyant Heinrich Klaasen has also been unable to strike the ball consistently and Nitish Reddy too has been patchy.\n\nThe bowlers have fared better compared to their batting counterparts. T Natarajan has been consistent with the ball while seasoned seamer Bhuvneshwar Kumar also seems to have found his mojo after his incisive spell helped SRH eke out a one-run win against RR.\n\nLSG, on the other hand, have to get over their overall lacklustre display against Kolkata Knight Riders, when they not only conceded the first-ever 200 plus score at the Ekana Stadium but also folded their innings at 137. It was a day when skipper KL Rahul failed to anchor the innings while the likes of Marcus Stoinis and Nicholas Pooran were unable to get the big shots when needed.\n\nAyush Badoni has had a subdued run in this IPL and the uncapped Indian player would be keen to shrug off the rustiness. LSG's struggles with the ball have been majorly due to the lack of firepower in their pace-bowling department.\n\nWith tearaway pacer Mayank Yadav ruled out of the IPL and left-arm pacer Mohsin Khan also picking up an injury, the onus will be on Afghan quick Naveen-ul-Haq, young Yash Thakur, Stoinis and spinners Krunal Pandya and Ravi Bishnoi to deliver.\n\nSquads:\n\nSunrisers Hyderabad: When the opposition team has Travis Head, Heinrich Klaasen, your intention should be to go at 10s and over. 160-170 will never be enough,\" Hayden said in commentary.\n\nInterestingly, the way LSG batters batted made many believe that the pitch was not good for strokeplay. Even LSG head coach Justin Langer said that 160 would be a good total. But as it turned out, it was nowhere near being enough.\n\nTravis Head and Abhishek Sharma chased it down in record quick time. The dynamic SRH opening pair scored 166 runs in 9.4 overs - the most by any team inside 10 overs in the history of IPL. Head hit eight fours and as many sixes to remain undefeated at 89 off just 30 balls. His uncapped Indian was not too far behind. Abhishek blasted 75* off 28 balls, hitting eight fours and six sixes.\n\nThe win propelled SRH to the third position in the standings with 14 points from 12 games, while LSG are struggling at the sixth spot with 12 points from the same number of matches.\n\nThe result also meant that five-time champions Mumbai Indians, currently ninth with eight points from 12 matches, are out of the playoff race.\n\nThis was LSG's second big loss on the trot. {"uri": "8118513363", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "05:26:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T05:26:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T05:26:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.rediff.com/cricket/report/ipl-2024-abhishek-sharma-exciting-talent-for-indian-cricket-head/20240509.htm", "title": "Abhishek Sharma exciting talent for Indian cricket: Head", "body": "IMAGE: Abhishek Shamra and Travis put up a record stand for the opening wicket to power SRH to a crushing win over LSG. Photograph: BCCI\n\nThe destructive Travis Head has called his Sunrisers Hyderabad opening partner Abhishek Sharma an exciting talent for Indian cricket after the duo combined to pummel the Lucknow Super Giants bowling attack in a record IPL chase in Hyderabad.\n\nSCORECARD\n\nHead (89 not out off 30) and Sharma (75 not out off 28), who have formed one of the most explosive pairings in the IPL this season, made a mockery of the 166-run target by overhauling it in just 9.4 overs. It was the highest ever 10 over score in history of men's T20 cricket.\n\nBoth the southpaws hit fours and sixes for fun in what was a sensational display of power-hitting.\n\n\"The partnership with Abhi has been fantastic, he's such an exciting talent for Indian cricket.\n\n\"We complement each other so well and he's very very enjoyable to be around, he's so excited and thinks about the game and yeah he's got a lot of energy so it's a great partnership to be involved in,\" said Head in the post-match press conference on Wednesday.\n\nHead is in top form ahead of the T20 World Cup in the Americas next month, having aggregated 533 runs in 11 innings at an astonishing strike rate of 201.89. Sharma too has been striking at over 200.\n\n\"Whenever you're playing you want to be as consistent as you can, you want to be getting runs. It's nice to be among the runs been nice to be playing well. That's not going to guarantee anything in the West Indies but it gives me the best chance to be in a very good mindset,\" said Head.\n\n\"Working hard on training and I think we face a fair bit of spin in the Caribbean and wickets might become tougher as the tournament goes. So very pleased with how I played spin tonight, things that I'm working on in training are somewhat working in the moment,\" he added.\n\nSharma had also earned high praise from West Indies legend Brian Lara, who is a former coach of SRH.\n\n\"Again he is someone who I met while I was batting coach of SRH. I spent two years there. I am allowed to a bit biased when I see a left-hander, I just love a left-hander.\n\nIPL 2024\n\n\"Myself and Abhishek have developed a very good relationship, these youngsters are very humble. they The winner will move to number three and keep qualification to the playoffs in their control. The loser would slip/remain out of the top four and would get heavily reliant on other teams' failures to move to the next round.\n\nAlthough both teams have relied heavily on their batting line-ups to win most of their games, this one, on one of the flattest tracks in the tournament, could be decided by which team bowls better. Below, we have predicted three bowlers who can take the most wickets and put up match-winning shows for their teams:\n\n3 bowlers who could pick up the most wickets in today's SRH vs LSG match\n\n#3 Naveen-ul-Haq\n\nDespite his struggles in the last game, Naveen-ul-Haq has been one of LSG's best bowlers in IPL 2024 with 10 wickets from seven games at an average of 23.40.\n\nAs LSG have found success with their Indian bowling contingent, Naveen has quietly picked up at least one wicket in six of these games. He doesn't have express pace, swing, or seam movement but is one of the most street-smart bowlers with a bag of tricks that keeps the batters guessing.\n\nThat's exactly what he used against Kolkata Knight Riders' biggest hitters Phil Salt, Andre Russell, and Rinku Singh in LSG's previous match. On Wednesday, he'll have the responsibility to get the wickets of Travis Head, Abhishek Sharma, or both in the early stages, while also contributing in the middle and death overs. Thanks to his form, he'd have a good chance of coming on top.\n\n#2 Pat Cummins\n\nOn flat tracks, it's hard to overlook Pat Cummins for bowling predictions. The SRH captain is a master of meticulous planning and execution, bowls important overs, and picks important wickets even if other bowlers are struggling. He has shown that by picking six wickets from four games in Uppal in IPL 2024.\n\nFor a team struggling with its batting positioning, lacking in confidence, and relying on a couple of players to get them through, Cummis is the most difficult nemesis to face. He'll take the most difficult overs in the innings but they'll also be the ones who could get him the most wickets, depending on the match situation.\n\nKL Rahul has got out to him once in IPL while other LSG batters haven't faced the new version of him.\n\n#1 Bhuvneshwar Kumar\n\nAfter struggling for wickets in the first half of the season, Bhuvneshwar Kumar has roared back to form with five wickets in the last three games.\n\nHis best spell of the season came in Uppal against Rajasthan Royals -- a brilliant, Player-of-the-Match worthy 3/41. Against LSG, who have similar problems against swing, Kumar would have his tails up in the powerplay, also because he has a good IPL record against Rahul, Quinton de Kock, Marcus Stoinis, and Nicholas Pooran.\n\nHe'll also be happy to bowl two overs at the death to expose LSG's shallow batting order. Abhishek attributed his approach to the Syed Mushtaq Ali Trophy, where he played a crucial role in Punjab's victory. He expressed admiration for Head's spin-playing skills, saying he's \"a big fan\" and that their understanding and friendship have contributed to their success. Abhishek also revealed their strategy against LSG's pacers, using their spins to hit long shots.\n\nThe unwavering support from skipper Pat Cummins and the entire think-tank played a big role in his success in the on-going IPL, reckoned Sunrisers Hyderabad opener Abhishek Sharma. The 23-year-old Punjab left-hander fired from all cylinders for Hyderabad this season, making 401 runs from 12 matches and those runs have come at an awesome strike-rate of 205. ''Our support staff and Pat (Cummins), the way they think, I have never seen anyone else think like that,'' Abhishek said on JioCinema Match Centre Live after their record 10-wicket win over Lucknow Super Giants here on Wednesday.\n\n''They're like, 'Go out there and express yourself. Play as aggressively as you can, we'll back you.' I think that matters a lot,'' said Abhishek, who has hit 35 sixes so far, highest by any batter this season. The SRH openers Abhishek (75 not out off 28 balls) and Travis Head (89 not out off 30 balls) scaled down 166 in just 9.4 overs, rewriting the record for the quickest chase of 150-plus in T20 cricket.\n\nSRH's total of 167 was also the highest by any team by the end of the tenth over in men's T20s.\n\n''I think this approach was something I took on during the Syed Mushtaq Ali Trophy,'' said Abhishek who played a key role in Punjab winning the domestic T20 title last season.\n\nAbhishek (485 runs from 10 matches) was the second highest run-getter behind Riyan Parag (510) of Assam in last season's SMAT.\n\n''I feel when I play this way, look at the ball, and react, my shots come off better and the bowler comes under pressure. I always thought if I play in the IPL, I'll try to maintain this,'' he added. 'Big fan of Head' =========== With Head at his explosive best, SRH have smashed many batting records this season including the highest ever IPL total of 287/3 against Royal Challengers Bengaluru.\n\nAbhishek hailed the way Head played spin.\n\n''I don't think anyone plays spin better than Travis. The shots he hit off (Krishnappa) Gowtham, normally batters can't do that, that shows how special he is. ''He's very clear, whenever I talk to him, the way he compliments me, I have always been a big fan of him over the last year that I have followed him.\n\n''When our understanding was established and our partnership improved, we became good friends off the pitch and have started spending more time,'' he added.\n\nAbhishek then touched upon his strategy against the LSG bowlers, especially pacers. ''They were bowling cutters in the middle. I thought the cutters could slow down on their way, but Travis and I had planned to play it the way you would hit a spinner with the spin.\n\n''So, if it's an off-cutter, we look to hit towards long-off covers. {"uri": "8117857607", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "17:59:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T17:59:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T17:59:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://apnews.com/article/ipl-hyderabad-lucknow-score-187c7a941dedbe3ff54f7ca31d47a51e", "title": "Head and Sharma's electrifying opening stand earns Hyderabad 10-wicket win over Lucknow", "body": "HYDERABAD, India (AP) -- The opening pair of Travis Head and Abhishek Sharma shared a massive 167-run stand as Sunrisers Hyderabad required just 58 balls to rout Lucknow Super Giants by 10 wickets in the Indian Premier League on Wednesday.\n\nHead and Sharma cranked 16 fours and 14 sixes in an extraordinary display of power-hitting in the first-ever IPL game that saw so many runs being scored inside the first 10 overs.\n\nHead has been scoring consistently for the batting power-house of Hyderabad this season and raced to his half-century off 16 balls before he eventually finished on an unbeaten 89 off 30 balls.\n\nSharma followed the Australian left-hander soon when he reached his 50 off 19 balls as they raced to century-stand inside the batting power play. Sharma regained his lost touch with an undefeated 75 off 28 balls.\n\nThe win lifted Hyderabad to No. 3 with 14 points and more importantly gave it a healthy net run-rate of 0.41 with two home games to go. The huge defeat has pushed Lucknow in the tight corner for the playoffs with 12 points from 12 games.\n\nEarlier, Ayush Badoni (55) and Nicholas Pooran (48) propelled Lucknow to 165-4 with a 99-run unbeaten fifth-wicket stand after Bhuvneshwar Kumar (2-12) gave away just 12 singles and dismissed the big hitters -- Quinton de Kock (2) and Marcus Stoinis (3) -- inside the power play.\n\nHead and Sharma charged against pace and spin as Yash Thakur was smashed for 47 off his 16 balls while spinners Ravi Bishnoi and Krishnappa Gowtham gave away 63 runs off their four overs.\n\nLucknow had a moment to separate the destructive pair but Thakur couldn't hold onto a sharp one-handed catch of Sharma at short third-man when the batter was on 18 in the third over. Sharma had another escape after completing his half-century when leg-spinner Bishnoi dropped a hard two-handed return catch.\n\nEarlier, Kumar had buckled down Lucknow 27-2 in the first six overs on a tacky wicket and Rahul struggled to give the innings momentum before pulled skipper Pat Cummins to deep backward square leg and got dismissed for struggling 29 off 33 balls.\n\nPooran and Badoni
