Notably, chasing 236 runs, Rahul gave a very slow start to Lucknow and got out after scoring 25 runs off 21 deliveries. As per Lee, his knock put pressure on the other batters as the hosts never looked comfortable. In the end, they lost by 98 runs and moved down to fifth on the points table.\n\nLee mentioned that KKR openers Phil Salt and Sunil Narine were terrific and believed that their partnership of 70 runs made the difference. Both Salt and Narine were aggressive right from the start, unlike LSG players, who took some time to settle down. Lee stated that KL Rahul's run-a-ball innings did not help Lucknow and that led to their downfall.\n\nAlso Read - KL Rahul analyses LSG's crushing defeat to KKR at Ekana\n\n\"I think if you look at both opening batters from both sides, it's a complete contrast. KKR have got it right. They're out of the blocks quickly, they're scoring runs. And then you got KL Rahul on the other side, that's, you know, getting a run a ball and putting a lot of pressure on the back end. You know, we saw four games and I picked KL Rahul here, the first four games he played,\" Lee said on Jio Cinema.\n\n\"His strike rate was 129, then he went to 150 and now he's come back and said, 'well, yeah, you know the bowlers have done a great job. I think there's a lot of pressure on him because he hasn't scored the runs he should be,\" the former pacer added.\n\nAlso Read - How can Lucknow Super Giants qualify for playoffs after loss against KKR?\n\nMeanwhile, Lucknow will next play Sunrisers Hyderabad, followed by matches against Delhi Capitals and Mumbai Indians - all away from home. {"uri": "2024-05-346138490", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:37:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:37:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T07:27:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3411764800548553, "url": "https://www.sportskeeda.com/cricket/news-then-got-kl-rahul-side-brett-lee-questions-lsg-skipper-s-lack-intent-run-chase-kkr-ipl-2024-match", "title": "\"Then you got KL Rahul on the other side\" - Brett Lee questions LSG skipper's lack of intent during run-chase against KKR in IPL 2024 match", "body": "Former Australian pacer Brett Lee has expressed concerns about Lucknow Super Giants skipper KL Rahul's strike rate in IPL 2024, saying it puts too much pressure on other batters. The New South Wales lad observed how the Kolkata Knight Riders' top-order batters have been getting off the blocks quickly to give their side the required headstart.\n\n32-year-old Rahul, who has won the Orange cap in IPL on multiple occasions, has a career strike rate of 135.04 and has maintained a strike rate of 141.03 in the ongoing edition. However, the right-handed batter struck only at 119.04 with 25 off 21 deliveries when the Super Giants were chasing 236 for victory against the Kolkata Knight Riders on Sunday.\n\nSpeaking on JioCinema, Lee opined that Rahul is under pressure because of his underwhelming returns with the bat, saying:\n\n\"I think if you look at both opening batters from both sides, it's a complete contrast. KKR have got it right. They're out of the blocks quickly, they're scoring runs. And then you got KL Rahul on the other side, that's, you know, getting a run a ball and putting a lot of pressure on the back end.\"\n\n\"You know, we saw four games and I picked KL Rahul here, the first four games he played. His strike rate was 129, then he went to 150 and now he's come back and said, 'well, yeah, you know the bowlers have done a great job. I think there's a lot of pressure on him because he hasn't scored the runs he should be,\" Lee added.\n\nChasing a daunting 236, the Super Giants were nowhere in the game as Harshit Rana and Varun Chakravarthy shared six wickets between them to bowl the hosts out for 137.\n\n\"Poor performance overall with bat, ball and in the field\" - KL Rahul\n\nFollowing the 98-run defeat, KL Rahul said at the post-match presentation that LSG bowlers failed to recover from Sunil Narine and Phil Salt's assault at the outset. He elaborated:\n\n\"It was a lot of runs to be scored in the second innings. When you are chasing a big total, you are trying to go too hard and you end up losing wickets. Just a poor performance overall. The skill sets of the big hitters, which are their strengths and weapons, principally revolve around timing, pressuring the bowler and doing the math.\n\nUsing an aggressive mindset they can control the bowler and make him deliver the ball the way you want it. But it's not just all about aggression today's cricketers invest heavily in the mental side of the game as it is not as easy as it seems to pull off those great shots.\n\nThe great Viv Richards once said that cricket has become a batsman's game and is far removed from the day when the likes of Malcolm Marshall, Joel Garner, Dennis Lillee, Allan Donald or Wasim Akram terrorised the batters on the pitch.\n\nRichards, one of the hardest hitters of the cricket ball, felt pity for the bowlers who were at the mercy of swords that the batsmen wielded, denied by batting-friendly pitches and small boundaries.\n\nWhile the flat decks at the ongoing IPL might have heavily favoured the batsmen, it is conceivable that the balance will be restored during this summer's ICC T20 World Cup in the USA and West Indies.\n\nAs we saw during the 2010 T20 World Cup, the pitches in the West Indies are not tailored for high scoring. The climate and timing of the matches are also sure to have a huge impact and make it more challenging for the batters. The dry pitches in the Caribbean will rough up the ball quicker paving the way for spinners to work their magic and test the batters, unlike in the IPL.\n\nWith Royal Challengers Bengaluru, one of the most talent-rich sides to have never won the tournament, star batter Virak Kohli appeared to be feeling the weight of expectations when he hit out at expert commentators like Sunil Gavaskar for questioning his strike-rate and chinks against spin bowling.\n\nGavaskar hit back at the star batter for seeking 'appreciation for a strike-rate of 118' and also received the support of Pakistan cricket great Wasim Akram who felt that Kohli should not have said what he did.\n\n\"Both are proud Indians; both are greats. It's OK; they both will move in pretty quickly. I don't think either will take it personally. They will be fine, I know. I am telling you now. I know them both very well,\" Akram said.\n\nFor the record, Kohli's overall strike rate this season in the IPL is 148.08, which is very good for someone who has scored 542 runs.\n\nBut it's the intrepid style of players like Head, whose 533 runs in 11 matches have been scored at a mindboggling striking of 201.89, that has completely changed the dynamics of the game.\n\nIt's not going to be easy, though, to carry on with his cavalier style when the World Cup starts next month in the West Indies and the US.\n\nEven Head, whose 30-ball unbeaten 89 helped Sunrrisers chase down 165 in just 9.4 overs against Lucknow Super Giants on Wednesday, knows that it's going to be a different ballgame the World Cup.\n\n\"Whenever you're playing, you want to be as consistent as you can, you want to be getting runs. It's nice to be playing well (but) that's not going to guarantee anything in the West Indies,\" said Head.\n\n\"I think we'll face a fair bit of spin in the Caribbean and the wickets might become tougher as the tournament goes on.\"\n\nWhen there is a fair contest between the bat and the ball, it's the classy batters like Kohli that thrive.", "source": {"uri": "khaleejtimes.com", "dataType": Despite the pitch being on the slower side, fans expressed significant disappointment over Rahul's batting, which they felt bogged down the team's innings.\n\nThe match unfolded on a notably sluggish pitch, but fans argued that this did not justify Rahul's overly cautious approach. His performance became a flashpoint on social media, where fans voiced their frustration and concern over his form.\n\nOn Twitter, one fan expressed, \"Kl Rahul is so frustrating to watch lol, how does LSG fans survive through this week in and out?\" highlighting the exasperation among the spectators watching his defensive play.\n\nAnother echoed similar sentiments about the pitch conditions not being an excuse for such a slow scoring rate, stating, \"Pitch is slow But not this much,\" coupled with a critique of Rahul's recent performance against SRH.\n\nSome fans speculated on strategic play by opponents, with a tweet suggesting, \"Pat Cummins using the same do not get KL Rahul out when he's batting strategy,\" referring to a previous match where Cummins' Australian team benefited from Rahul's sluggish innings in the crucial World Cup Final 2023 last year.\n\nAccusations of selfish play were rampant.
